questions.text: When making a routine DSC call to another vessel what information should be included?

questions.text: When sending a DSC call:

questions.text: A "Distress Hot Key" VHF DSC Distress alert:

questions.text: A "Distress Hot Key" alert will always include what information?

answers.A: Operators cannot initiate acknowledgements or relays.

questions.text: Which of the following statements on DSC acknowledgement and relay of DSC Distress alerts is true?

answers.D: It will initiate the DSC Distress alert, but any station receiving it will have to establish contact with the   distressed vessel to determine its identity, position, and situation.

questions.text: What does the DSC control unit do if the GMDSS Radio Operator fails to insert updated information when initiating a DSC Distress alert?

answers.D: Advise the Master and monitor Ch-16.
answers.C: No action is necessary.
answers.B: Call the nearest Coast Guard Station.
answers.A: Transmit a DSC acknowledgement.

answers.B: Make a "MAYDAY" call on Ch-70.
answers.A: Press the "Distress Hot Key".

questions.text: What is the quickest method of transmitting a DSC Distress alert?

answers.D: Are the best means to provide for a retransmission of Distress communications.
answers.C: Should be transmitted to all ships involved in Distress traffic.
answers.B: Should be avoided; unless an acknowledgement has not been heard.
answers.A: Should be done for all Distress alerts received aboard the ship.

questions.text: DSC relays of Distress alerts by vessels:

answers.D: Position, time of position update, MMSI number programmed and Distress priority specifier.
answers.C: Position, UTC time of position update and Ch-70 for voice follow-on.
answers.B: A "Nature of Distress" category and Distress priority specifier code.
answers.A: Distress designation and follow on communications channel.

questions.text: A VHF-DSC "Distress Hot Key" alert always transmits what information if connected to GPS?

answers.D: The vessel nearest to the emergency must notify the Coast Guard before leaving the vicinity.
answers.C: Ship-to-ship Distress alerts are used to alert other ships in the vicinity of navigational hazards and bad weather.
answers.B: Ship to shore Distress alerts are used to alert other ships in port of navigational hazards.
answers.A: The Distress alert must identify the station in Distress and its position and may additionally include information regarding the nature of the Distress.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Distress alerting under GMDSS?

answers.D: The receiving station will poll the DSC unit of the vessel in Distress to download the necessary information.
answers.C: The transmission is not initiated and "ERROR" is indicated on the display readout.
answers.B: The transmission will be made with "default" information provided automatically.

answers.A: Ship's position, nature of distress and assistance requested.

answers.C: Ship stations that receive a Distress alert from a vessel in their vicinity must immediately send a DSC relay to inform the RCC.
answers.B: A ship station that receives a Distress alert must, as soon as possible, inform the Master or person responsible for the ship of the contents of the Distress alert.
answers.A: Ship stations in receipt of a Distress alert should acknowledge it immediately to assist the coast station in responding to the Distress alert.

answers.D: Set watch on the radiotelephone Distress and Safety frequency associated with the Distress and Safety calling frequency on which the Distress alert was received.

answers.A: Set watch on the DSC alerting frequency in the band of frequencies the alert was received.

answers.D: Silence the alarm and set up watch on Ch-16 to determine if the Distress is genuine.

answers.B: Silence the alarm, examine the display screen and acknowledge the DSC alert via DSC.

questions.text: What action should be taken on receipt of a VHF Distress alert?

answers.D: If there are errors in the call the unit didn't auto-acknowledge via DSC and the watch officer must do so instead.
answers.C: No precautions are necessary -- the unit will auto-acknowledge an incoming DSC Distress alert.
answers.B: If the message is not clear make a DSC call to all ships requesting clarification.
answers.A: Be careful not to activate a DSC acknowledgement or relay.

questions.text: What precautions should be taken when viewing an incoming DSC Distress alert message?

answers.D: DSC Distress Relays do not need to be made if your vessel is too far away to assist.
answers.C: After there is an acknowledgement from a coast station.
answers.B: When the MMSI of the vessel in Distress cannot be determined.
answers.A: When a DSC response to a Distress alert from a Coast/Ship Station hasn't been received and the Master approves.

questions.text: A DSC Distress Relay should always be made under the following circumstances:

answers.D: Transmit a voice "Mayday Relay" call on Ch-13.
answers.C: Monitor Ch-06 to determine if there are any genuine Distress communications.
answers.B: Monitor Ch-16 to determine if there are any genuine Distress communications.
answers.A: Retransmit the DSC call on Ch-70 to other vessels in the vicinity.

questions.text: Your ship received a Distress relay from a coast station on DSC VHF channel 70. What action should the watch officer take?

answers.D: No distress traffic has been heard and the DSC alert is unacknowledged via DSC.
answers.C: A coast station DSC acknowledgment of the original Distress alert was received by your vessel.
answers.B: If no Coast Station/Mobile Unit acknowledgement of the alert is observed.
answers.A: If the mobile unit in Distress is incapable of further Distress alert communications.

questions.text: Under what condition would you not relay a DSC Distress alert?

answers.D: Can quickly overburden the GMDSS systems in the vicinity with improperly transmitted or inappropriately relayed DSC calls.
answers.C: Should always be done immediately to ensure a Coast Station receives the DSC Distress Alert.
answers.B: Remains the preferred method for passing Distress message traffic to an RCC or Coast Station.
answers.A: Was not originally an intended function of the GMDSS system but now is the preferred method to notify an RCC.

questions.text: The relay of DSC Distress alerts:

answers.D: When the responsible person at the Coast Station determines further help is necessary.
answers.C: When the Master or responsible person on the mobile unit not in Distress so decides.
answers.B: When the mobile unit actually in Distress is not itself in a position to transmit the Distress alert.
answers.A: When communications between the Distress vessel and a Coast station are already in progress.

questions.text: Transmission of a Distress alert by a station on behalf of another vessel actually in Distress should not occur:

answers.D: Call the Coast Station on Ch-70 with Distress priority giving the other vessel's position.

answers.A: Send a DSC Distress Relay transmission on Ch-16.

answers.C: Make a voice announcement to cancel the alert on Ch-22A.
answers.B: Make a voice announcement to cancel the alert on Ch-13.
answers.A: Send a DSC cancellation message on Ch-70.

questions.text: What action should you take after sending a false Distress alert on VHF?

answers.D: Turn off the power and make a voice announcement to cancel the alert on Ch-70.
answers.C: No specific action is necessary.
answers.B: Send a DSC call canceling the Distress alert.
answers.A: Stop the radio from repeating the alert then make an all stations call on Ch-16 canceling the inadvertent alert.

questions.text: A crewmember has accidentally transmitted a VHF-DSC Distress alert. What action should be taken?

answers.D: Ensure that all officers read the operating manuals and are familiar with the menus.
answers.C: Ensure that the protective cover over the "Distress Hot Key" is secure.
answers.B: Disabling the unit's ability to perform DSC Relays & acknowledgments.
answers.A: Proper watch officer instruction and training.

questions.text: What action is not applicable in preventing transmissions of false Distress alerts?

answers.C: Contact the nearest coast station or RCC to cancel the distress alert and subsequently disable the EPIRB.
answers.B: Contact the nearest USCG Coast Station and request that they send the alert reset signal.
answers.A: Disabling the EPIRB is all that is necessary.

questions.text: The EPIRB on the bridge wing is observed with the strobe light flashing and the control switch in the "ON" position. What action(s) should be taken?

answers.D: Your own vessel's EPIRB homing beacon has been activated.
answers.C: Your own vessel's SART has been activated.
answers.B: There is a fault in the radar.
answers.A: There is a survival craft within 3 nm distance.

questions.text: You have been monitoring your 3-cm radar screen and a series of 12 concentric circles suddenly appears centered on the screen. What is the most likely cause of this situation?

answers.C: Wait for the USCG or NOAA to confirm that the unit is actually transmitting.
answers.B: No action is needed - the strobe light indicates the automatic monthly self test is in progress.

questions.text: The EPIRB on the bridge wing is observed with the strobe light flashing and the control switch in the "OFF" position. What action should be taken?

answers.D: To ensure that a Distressed vessel will have a "window" twice each hour for transmitting routine messages.

answers.B: To ensure that only voice communications can be effected on the Distress frequency or channel.
answers.A: To ensure that interference to proprietary communications is minimized.

questions.text: What is the fundamental purpose for imposing radio silence?

answers.C: If, in the master's opinion, communications on that frequency will interfere with emergency communications.
answers.B: After determining that geographic distance from the Distress situation will prohibit any other signal from interfering with emergency communications.
answers.A: After determining that the frequency or channel appears to be no longer in use.

questions.text: When can routine communications be resumed when radio silence has been imposed?

answers.D: Communications on a Distress frequency or channel is banned for 24 hours following the cessation of the Distress traffic.
answers.C: Two three-minute silent periods, at 15 and 45 minutes after the hour, that provide a transmitting "window" for distressed vessels to transmit Distress alerts using J3E.
answers.B: Stations remaining off the air to safeguard proprietary information.
answers.A: Stations not directly involved with the on-going Distress communications may not transmit on the Distress frequency or channel.

questions.text: What is meant by the term "Seelonce Mayday"?

answers.D: By the vessel first responding to the Distress call.

questions.text: How is "radio silence" imposed?

answers.B: To prevent interference to Distress communications.
answers.A: To keep a clear channel open for Safety broadcasts.

answers.C: The Rescue Coordination Center (RCC) that imposed the radio silence must transmit a voice message on the Distress frequency stating "SEELONCE FEENEE".
answers.B: The Land Earth Station (LES) that imposed the radio silence must transmit a voice message on the Distress frequency stating "SILENCE FINI".
answers.A: All of these answers are correct.

questions.text: Which of the following situations would normally use the Safety priority?
